text: *Iron deficiency anemia*: in addition to the typical low ferritin, low MCV, it is associated with HIGH TRANSFERRIN (aka high TIBC)

*Methylmalonyl acidemia*: associated with an AR organic acidemia, resulting from complete or partial deficiency of methylmalonyl-CoA mutase, which converts methylmalonyl-CoA to Succinyl-CoA; leads to a buidup of methylmalonyl-CoA, proprionyl-CoA which is excreted in urine

*Methylmalonyl acidemia*: can present with lethargy, vomiting, tachypnia (acidosis) in newborn; labs show ketotic hypoglycemia, metabolic acidosis; compare to Cori disease, which also includes hepatomegaly with fatty change
*Scaled-skin syndrome*: exotoxin exfolatin from Staph can cause widespread sloughing of the epidermis, even with gentle pressure (Nikolsky's sign)
*Lecithin*: aka dipalmatoyl phosphatidlcholine, the one of the major constituents of pulmonary surfactant; the other one being phosphatidylglycerol
*Lecithin / Sphingomyelin ratio*: this ratio is good > 2.0 at third trimester; compares a surfactant component with a common membrane phospholipid
*Kleinfelter syndrome*: one of the few chromosomal count diseases that can present with relatively mild mental disability
*Type 1 diabetes*: can present in late adolescence or early adulthood; can also present as unexplained weight loss with fatigue, polydipsia, polyuria
*Reactive arthritis*: in addition to being cause by the classical UTI of chlamydia, this condition can also be precipitated by infection with _Salmonella, Shigella, Yersina, C. diff_

*Henloch-Schlonlein purpura (HSP)*: most common small vessel vasculitis in children; can additionally present with intermittent abdominal pain as well as self-limited migratory arthralgias and arthritis
*Coronary sinus*: located near the atrioventricular sulcus; left ventricular leads in biventricular pacemakers course through here

*Dressler's syndrome*: post-MI pericarditis that begins one week to a few months after acute MI; mediated by autoimmune reaction to self-antigens released in injury, compare to early onset pericarditis post-MI, which is an inflammatory reaction of pericardium adjacent to necrotizing cardiac muscle (e.g. leaky pro-inflammatory exudates)

*Inspiration and pulmonary vascular resistance*: increased lung volumes cause length-wise stretching of the pulmonary vessels, increasing their length and reducing their diameter, thereby increasing pulmonary resistance

*Expiration and pulmonary vascular resistance*: decreasing lung volumes cause compression via positive intrathoracic pressure and decreased radial traction from adjacent tissues, thereby increasing pulmonary resistance
*Functional residual capacity*: the volume at the bottom of a tidal breath; time of lowest pulmonary resistance
*Ventricular arrythmia*: can occur ~14 days after MI due to scar formation leading to conduction abnormalities; death usually follows
*Uterosacro ligaments*: these ligaments connect the uterus with the anterior portion of the sacrum
*CN V3*: provides general sensory (touch, pain, pressure, temperature) to anterior 2/3rds of tongue
*Reverse T3*: inactive form of thyroid hormone that is generated almost entirely from the peripheral conversion of T4
*Liothyronine*: aka synthetic thyroid T3; not usually used due to shorter half-life than levothyroxine; administration results in reduced serum TSH, Reverse T3, and endogenous T4
*Right ventricular diastolic, right atrial, central venous pressure*: these areas in vasculature have a diastolic pressure of 1-6 mmHg
*Pulmonary artery diastolic pressure*: these areas in vasculature have a diastolic pressure of 6-12 mmHg due to resistance in pulmonary circuit
*Right ventricular systolic, pulmonary systolic pressure*: these areas in vasculature have a systolic pressure of 25mmHg
*Left atrial, pulmonary capillary wedge pressure, and left ventricular diastolic pressure*: these areas in vasculature have a MEAN pressure of around 6-12mmHg
*Serine kinases*: activation of these proteins induces insulin resistance; TNF-alpha, catecholamines, glucocorticoids, glucagon work by this mechanism
*Insulin receptor signalling*: this signalling pathway involves autophosphorylation of IR, phosphorylation of IR substrates, and then translocation of GLUT4 on adipose and skeletal muscle membrane
*Serine kinases*: these kinases phosphorylate residues on IR and IRS-1, inhibiting tyrosine phosphorylation of IRS-1 by IR and prevents translocation of GLUT4 into the membrane
*Postpartum hemorrhage*: if unresponsive to typical medical management (e.g. uterine massage, uterotonic medications), this complication of atony is treated with bilateral internal iliac ligation
*Elevated free fatty acid levels*: contribute to insulin resistance by impairing insulin-dependent glucose uptake and increasing hepatic  gluconeogenesis
*Renal plasma flow*: can be calculated with PAH clearance; which in turn is estimated via PAH clearance = (PAH_urine/PAH_blood)*(Urine flow rate)
*Renal blood flow*: how much blood flows into the kidney, compare to how much plasma flows through the kidney over a certain amount of time
*Renal blood flow*: can be calculated by RPF/(1-Hematocrit)
*Influenza*: vaccine comprises neutralizing antibodies against hemagluttinin antigen in selected viral strains, preventing viral entry
*Outcomes of association (e.g. relative risk, odds ratio)*: if similar between studies it is likely that design flaws (e.g. poor blinding, researcher expectancy) were present in the study of interest
*Vitamin C deficiency*: can also present as corkscrew hairs and perifollicular hemorrhages on skin findings; results in defective function of collagen synthesis enzymes in the *RER*

*DNA Enhancer sequences*: these DNA sequences bind to activator proteins that facilitate bending of DNA; this in turn allows interaction with general transcription factors; compare to promoter sequences which are 25/75 bp upstream
*DNA silencer sequences*: these DNA sequences bind to repressor proteins that decrease transcription rates
